repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
There may not be a huge value in this (if nothing else, CPython doesn't have this check, although I expect they eventually will) but guard against initialization of an async generator while it's already in progress.

I've chosen to raise an exception but other reasonable options would be to skip it (and assume the order doesn't matter) or to block until the first thread finishes (which is a little harder to arrange without making objects bigger).  Given this is to guard against fairly silly user-code I don't think this matters.

This only handles the initialization part. The rest of the file remains as is.

comment_data.body: Possibly debatable if this is the best place for this test, but nowhere else is more obvious
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -133,3 +133,39 @@ def test_gen_is_running():
 
     inner_instance = inner()
     return inner_instance
+
+def test_gen_concurrent_initialization():

comment_data.body: Seems a good time to move the `Atomics` to a separate file, although rather in a separate PR. They are not memoryview specific and not unlikely to get used in a few more places over time.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -211,21 +221,25 @@ __Pyx_async_gen_init_hooks_firstiter(__pyx_PyAsyncGenObject *o, PyObject *firsti
 
 static CYTHON_INLINE int
 __Pyx_async_gen_init_hooks_done(__pyx_PyAsyncGenObject *o) {
-    return o->ag_hooks_inited != 0;
+#if CYTHON_ATOMICS && CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON_FREETHREADING
+    return __pyx_atomic_load(&(o->ag_hooks_inited)) == 2;  // could be relaxed load in principle.
+#else
+    // Skip critical section even on CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON_FREETHREADING
+    // because practically this is a relaxed load. And also because it we really should have
+    // access to atomics there.

comment_data.body: I was considering whether we're bound to ABI compatibility here (the guarantee that  atomic ints have exactly `int` size seems weak) but I don't think we are. Foreign modules built with other Cython versions won't recognise the `AsyncGen` as such and must treat it as unknown async coroutine (with iteration capabilities).
Can't we wait for the other thread to finish instead? It doesn't seem an unavoidable fatal error to have two threads attempt the initialisation at the same time.

I don't think so here. But maybe I should move it to the end just in case.  There's at least a sanity check on the size of the class on module import though.

(I think there may be ABI issues with `__pyx_atomic_int_type` in memoryviews that we're currently ignoring though. Although no-one's reported bug so they're probably not too common)

Spinning and waiting would be easy (although likely wouldn't work on PyPy). Anything else would require some extra synchronization primitive which seems excessive.

If we don't want an error it'd be easier to just return. That'd match the existing behaviour (except for clearing up a small race). The finalizer would be fine because that would never get called until both threads have finished.  So it's mainly that one thread could be working before the `first_iter_hook` has finished.
#7032 - I'll come back to this PR after that's done.

commit.message:
Add thread-safety check to async-gen initialization

There may not be a huge value in this (if nothing else, CPython
doesn't have this check, although I expect they eventually will)
but guard against initialization of an async generator while
it's already in progress.

I've chosen to raise an exception but other reasonable options
would be to skip it (and assume the order doesn't matter)
or to block until the first thread finishes (which is a little
harder to arrange).  Given this is testing fairly silly
user-code I don't think this matters.

This only handles the initialization part. The rest of the
file remains as is.

title: Add thread-safety check to async-gen initialization
